title: New Perspectives on Land Dispossession, Violent Conflict and Migration in the West African Sahel
descriptions:
The proposed project, "New Perspectives on Land Dispossession, Violent Conflict and Migration in the West African Sahel," aims to investigate the complex interplay between land dispossession, violent resistance, and migration in the West African Sahel region, with a specific focus on Mali. By targeting farmers and pastoralists as key stakeholders, this project seeks to understand why some smallholders choose to resist violently while others remain compliant in the face of land dispossession. The central hypothesis posits that dispossessed smallholders are more likely to migrate or engage in violent resistance, with a particular emphasis on the role of 'jihadist' groups in these dynamics.

Utilizing a mixed methods approach informed by theoretical frameworks such as political ecology, critical agrarian studies, and peace and conflict studies, this project aims to generate novel insights into smallholder motivations and agency, as well as shed light on the intricate connections between land governance, violent conflicts, and migration. The expected outcomes include the production of new knowledge that can inform policy formulation and contribute to a deeper understanding of the socio-political dynamics at play in the Sahel region. Overall, this project has the potential to offer valuable insights into the root causes of land dispossession, violent conflict, and migration in the West African Sahel, ultimately contributing to more effective and sustainable interventions in this complex and dynamic context.
